reviewText: when buddy plays you just drop what youre doing and stare in awe. this jazz icon dvd is an absolute treasure. i just finished watching the whole dvd and find myself speechless. there are not enough superlatives to describe buddys playing. buddys band is on fire here to, and they would have to be to keep up with this guy! i found the video and audio to be superb. i have four of the jazz icon releases; thelonius monk, art blakey and dizzy gillespie. all are amazing and worth adding to your jazz collection. highly recommended!
Title: N/A

reviewerName: Jason P. Pumphrey "the movie & music man"
reviewText: Let me say this,being a drummer myself,I found this DVD invaluable!!! Getting to see the late great Buddy Rich in concert was pure heaven!!! This guy had it all speed,technique,stamina,etc!!! Truly incredible!!!Great tracks include Birdland,Big Swing Face and more,but the real treat is the tour de force"Five Channel Suite,complete with an incredible drum solo by Buddy!!! The rest of the band is tight!!! Great playing by all involved in this great Holland concert from 1978!!!  "Buddy Rich- Live in '78" is a superlative DVD!!! Two thumbs up!!! Way up! A+
summary: A must for the Buddy Rich fan!!! Drumming at it's very finest!!!
Title: N/A

reviewText: Maybe a notch below the DVD of Rich's 1982 Montreal Jazz Fest performance, but still essential.  Steve Marcus gets ample solo space and is outstanding.  The arrangement of Weather Report's "Birdland" is a standout.
Title: N/A

reviewText: This is a concert that everyone who loves big band jazz, fabulous drumming, great ensemble work, remarkable compositions and just plain being dazzled, this DVD is a must own!In previous reviews I read some criticism and you need to blow that off. The recorded concert is nearly thirty years ago and, for its time period, it's terrific! Great musicians are timeless. Recording technology has, of course, evolved.All that aside, the main thing is BUDDY! I love many of the modern day great drummers but NOBODY plays like Buddy. This was a blatant reminder of just how incredible he was. A freak of nature if you will. When God created the drum artist he chose Buddy to set the mark. Watching his left hand work is amazing! The absolute confidence in what he played will astound!Well............get it!
Title: N/A

reviewText: I have watched many videos, but as a drummer, Buddy Rich was in a class of his own, and personally I have never seen anybody come close to playing style, and virtual tap dancing around the drum set. He might have been a hard core band leader, but you just can't take his god given talent away. As most Buddy Rich Big Band videos and CD's, this one is another great video to watch the master at work, along with some of the hottest musicians of Jazz.
Title: N/A

reviewText: This is a great DVD for all Buddy Rich fans. He plays a lot of great tunes and is a must have for anyone who is a drum or Buddy Rich fan.
Title: N/A

reviewText: A lot of the reviewers here are going down a "jazz in the 70s" memory lane, which is fine, but for the rest of us, I'll add this caution: while this set is musically stellar as everyone here says -- these guys are TIGHT -- a large part of watching a DVD like this, as opposed to just listening to a recording from the same time period, is the visual element. This band is an assault on the eyes. White guys with afros! Shag haircuts and mustaches and aviator glasses! It's like a That 70s Show version of a jazz band. As fine as this music truly is, I just wanted to turn away in horror. When Buddy Rich is the most handsome guy on the stage, you KNOW you're in trouble. (And how is it that Rich, in 1978, could have an all-white big band? What's with that?)
Title: N/A

reviewText: From the opening Nestico chart "Ya' Gotta' Try" with barn-burning solo exchanges between Steve Marcus and Gary Pribek to the closing encore number "Big Swing Face" with an enduring extended tenor solo by Gary Pribek; this DVD cooks!This has by far the best version of Bob Kaye's "Grand Concourse" with Andy Fusco blowing chorus after chorus of imaginative improvisation. His solo is so hot that midway he makes a "statement" that elicits the approval of section-mates Steve Marcus and Chuck Wilson."Little Train" shows off the blowing talents of trumpeters Mike McGovern and John Marshall as well as the trombones of Dale Kirkland and Glen Franke, with Andy Fusco's hard -driving solo sandwiched between them."Channel One Suite" showcases Steve Marcus and his trademark solo interlude with touches of finger-snapping blues tenor interjected before his cadenza and then Buddy's extended solo.This is the best DVD of the Buddy Rich Big Band; even though Rich At The Top (1973) and Live At The Montreal Jazz Festival (1982) are no slouches.
summary: Great cohesion in this Big Band!
Title: N/A

reviewText: Unlike some listeners, I prefer the straightahead, swinging, Basie-indebted Rich ensemble of the late '70s to the somewhat ponderous, rock-heavy textures of the band assembled by Buddy during the late '60s. Even though this 1978 concert catches the band just after the departure of some key Rich players like trumpeter Dave Stahl and pianist Barry Kiener, it still features Buddy's right-hand man, tenor saxophonist Steve Marcus, along with a tight-knit ensemble of players with strong soloists in all sections.The program is a crowd-pleaser, with Nestico swingers, a fusion pop chart ("Birdland"), and one of Rich's two major drum solo vehicles ("Channel One Suite"), on which he doesn't disappoint. Visually, the camera man and editors are right on top of the action, providing long shots, close-ups, and angled shots that moreover follow the musical action.  Sonically, the DVD is a bit of a disappointment. The electric bass is frequently overly penetrating and "twangy," while Buddy's bass drum, snares, and toms are often muffled. The cymbals, moreover--both the crucial hi-hat and ride cymbal--are all but inaudible for much of the performance.Even if the concert originally was not planned for commercial release, how could the crew responsible for recording a performance by the world's most legendary drummer fail to adequately mic the drums?
summary: Legendary drummer, killer band, winning program, crack performance, well-edited video, fair audio.
Title: N/A
